description:
A good winter canyon – ankle-deep water only in normal flow conditions. Doable year-round but better in the cooler seasons because of the long walk. Abseil R7 passes through a large circular rock arch with a clear blue pool that looks like a pane of glass. There are beautiful views over the Wolgan Valley during both the walk and the canyon.

Approach

Four routes are possible. The first two options allow you to do the majority of the walking in the morning (~3 hrs) with only a short ~30 min downhill scramble to exit.

A car shuffle is technically possible but not worthwhile in practice as the time to drive between carparks is 1.5 hours and establishing the shuffle would take longer than walking.

Note: at present (early 2024) a long-term closure of Wolgan Road is still in place due to a landslip that occurred in February 2023, so Options 1, 1.1 and 2 are unfeasible.

Option 1: Scrub-bash up Penrose Gully

Parking: On Wolgan Road in an obvious clearing on the roadside, where the road makes a wide bend and directly opposite to the gullies draining the canyons. UTM coordinates: 56H 242956 6322108, Google Maps: https://goo.gl/maps/LXZGeBZf8ggFggtZ7. 2WD accessible. From the carpark, walk perpendicular to the road into the bush towards the Wolgan River. Cross the river at the log bridge just upstream and walk uphill until you join the Old Coach Track.

  • Turn right and follow the Old Coach Track until it meets Penrose Gully (56H 242634 6320814).
  • Follow the gully upstream. It is generally easiest scrambling up the boulders in the gully, as the sides are steep and crumbling.
  • Keep left at the first fork in the gully, and right at the second. You are aiming for a very small ramp/chute through the cliffline at 56H 243242 6320541. On satellite imagery, it is the right-hand crack on a section of cliff that appears as a fragment partly separated from the main cliffs by cracks on the left and right. Just above this point on the plateau is a great lookout.
  • Skirt around to the right, following the ridge up to the saddle (approx. 56H 243361 6320937) and into the gully on the opposite side (56H 243536 6321057). Follow this gully down to the first abseil.

Option 1.1. Kenobi Canyon and Jedi Point. Misses most of the scrub of option 1 but has some exposed scrambling: Parking and start: As per Option 1 Look for a rough climber track heading up to the left a couple hundred meters before the Penrose Gully track. Follow this up through breaks in the lower cliff lines to the base of the upper cliff line near Kenobi Canyon (56H 242961 6320962) (short micro canyon worth a look up) 50m north of Kenobi is a parallel slot (56H 242946 6321004) that will give access through the cliff line. This starts up an easy ramp but soon comes to a difficult boulder choke. Easiest way through the choke is to scramble into a alcove in the left wall just below the chock then up a 3m wall (grade 8 climb). First person up can drop a rope for others. Bit more scrambling and squeezing up the gully will get you to the outstanding views of Jedi Point.

From here there are several ways to access the Windows Gully upstream of the canyon including: a very scrubby walk down gully at (MR)431 211, the very narrow but pretty side canyon at (MR)432 211 or to avoid the majority of scrub in the upper creek simply head NNE and abseil in almost directly above the traditional first abseil.

Option 2: Mostly on-track walking using the Tigersnake Canyon route

Parking: as for Option 1


  • Start as for Option 1 but but remain on the Old Coach Track.
  • Follow this track all the way to the Tigersnake Canyon carpark at 56H 242512 6317970, avoiding turns to Glow Worm Tunnel.
  • Follow the Tigersnake entry route out along the ridge heading NE until you roughly in line with the gully at 56H 242507 6317965. The trail is relatively well-trodden but becomes indistinct after the Tigersnake turn-off – keep following the ridge.
  • Make your way into the gully and down to the first abseil.

Option 3: Parking at the Tigersnake carpark

This route is essentially the same as Option 2, but with the car at a different point, the walk-in is much shorter and the walk-out correspondingly longer. A reasonable option if you do Windows Tigersnake as a winter weekend trip or if Wolgan Road is closed.

Parking: at the Tigersnake Canyon carpark on Old Coach Road, at 56H 242512 6317970. Google maps: https://maps.app.goo.gl/L9Mk25jHV5V1i6cE8. Typically 2WD accessible.

  • Follow the Tigersnake entry route out along the ridge heading NE until you roughly in line with the gully at 56H 242507 6317965. The trail is relatively well-trodden but becomes indistinct after the Tigersnake turn-off – keep following the ridge.
  • Make your way into the gully and down to the first abseil.

Descent

{{pic|size=

X|Topo.png ~ Canyon topo}}


Exit

Depending on your approach option:

Options 1, 1.1 and 2

  • From the final abseil, scramble down the creekbed until you see stairs on either side. Climb up the stairs on the TL – this is where the Old Coach Track intersects the Windows Canyon gully, and you likely first joined the track this morning at this location.
  • Once you reach this point, turn right off the track almost immediately (56H 243010 6321812), walk downhill to the log bridge over the Wolgan River, and cross over back to the car.

Option 3

  • Begin the exit as for Options 1 and 2, but do not turn off the Old Coach Track. *Follow the track all the way around back to the Tigersnake carpark, ignoring turn-offs towards the Glow Worm Tunnel (see map in Approach section).

Red tape

Wolgan Road is affected by a long-term closure due to a landslip.

Beta sites

  • Windows Canyon - Sleep When We Are Dead

Trip reports and media
